awd_titl_txt: Research on modifying inverter controls in utility-scale renewables to emulate synchronous-generator voltages/currents under faults to retain existing protection infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
For combating the climate crisis, generating electricity from renewable resources, such as wind and solar, is essential. These resources are economical primarily in large scales and are often located far away from the metropolitan areas, hence need transmission lines. Protective relays are installed on these transmission lines to detect faults caused either by lighting or other short circuits, and disconnect faulted lines. The existing protection equipment is designed for electricity that is generated in power plants using conventional sources such as coal and natural gas. However, this protection infrastructure will not work with the existing control methods used in renewables-based generation. With many states opting to move towards hundred-percent generation by renewables, all existing protective relays will need to be replaced. The objective of the proposed research is to allow the existing protection equipment, such as relays, to continue to be used even as the electricity generation transitions from conventional sources to renewables, by controlling the renewable-based generation such that it emulates the conventional generation in the event of a fault. This will avoid incurring the huge cost of the system-wide upgrade of the protection infrastructure. The proposed approach is based on first determining the type of fault that has occurred and then to take appropriate action such that the existing relays perform as they do in the case of conventional sources.  This research will be a very important step in keeping the cost of renewables low in order to enhance their penetration into the utility grid. It will be transformative in advancing knowledge in the critical field of protecting the transmission infrastructure and becoming a norm used by hardware equipment manufacturers.  This research is at the intersection of power electronics, power systems, and controls, and will be very educational for the next generation of power engineers.

The objective of this proposal is to find a solution to the real and immediate need to enhance the integration of utility-scale renewables. Existing inverters of utility-scale renewable resources, such as PVs and wind, are controlled to generate balanced three-phase currents even during unbalanced faults. However, to operate, the commonly-used protection relays depend upon unbalanced currents that are generated, such as by the synchronous generators of conventional power plants during unbalanced faults. With the increasing penetration of such inverter-based resources, toward the goal of hundred-percent renewables, the existing protection schemes will not work. The proposed research is on injecting appropriate unbalanced current during faults so that the use of the existing transmission-protection infrastructure continues, without having to incur the huge cost of the system-wide upgrade of the protection infrastructure. The proposed approach is based on first identifying the type of fault that has occurred and then to inject the appropriate currents to make the relays operate, knowing only the inverter terminal voltages and the transformer-winding configuration. The proposed control scheme is based on emulating the time-tested behavior of conventional generators during faults, thus requiring no modifications in the existing protection infrastructure, i.e., the inverters operate based solely based on local measurements. This research will thoroughly investigate and develop the control scheme by software emulation and hardware verification. The research will also examine the impact of this control on the inverter components. The aim of the technology transfer is that the control scheme becomes a norm that can be mandated by transmission-system owners and independent power producers, who in turn, would require it of inverter manufacturers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Goal: The objective of this project was to find a solution to the real and immediate need to enhance the integration of utility-scale renewables. Existing inverters of utility-scale renewable resources, such as PVs and wind, are controlled to generate balanced three-phase currents even during unbalanced faults. However, to operate, the commonly used protection relays depend upon unbalanced currents that are generated, such as by the synchronous generators of conventional power plants during unbalanced faults.

With the increasing penetration of such inverter-based resources, toward the goal of hundred-percent renewables, the existing protection schemes will not work. The proposed research is on injecting appropriate unbalanced currents during faults so that the use of the existing transmission-protection infrastructure continues to operate, without having to incur the huge cost of the system-wide upgrade of the protection infrastructure.

Major Activities: The proposed control strategy was implemented, which controls the IBR to emulate synchronous generator fault behavior by maintaining the relative magnitudes and phase relationships of injected currents, within IBR maximum current injection limits. This control scheme was shown to replicate synchronous generator fault response at the relay measurement point, which is critical to ensure proper operation of protective devices. The voltage and current data from simulation was exported using the COMTRADE file format, which allows for playback of simulation data on relay hardware.

Five commercially available relays were programmed in the Xcel Energy relay testing laboratory, using typical protection settings. The goal is to ensure that existing protection devices continue to operate properly, regardless of IBR penetration levels in the transmission network. It was shown that this control strategy did allow the relays to operate properly, within expected fault clearing times. These results also meet the step response and settling time requirements of the new IEEE standard 2800, which includes fault current injection requirements for transmission connected IBRs.

These results were presented at the Texas A&M Conference for Protective Relay Engineers (paper published https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/9429836), the Minnesota Power Systems Conference, and a PhD thesis of a domestic student. A US patent was filed under application number PCT/US2021/023963.

It provided the PhD student an opportunity to work in the relay lab of Xcel Energy getting hands on experience with testing physical relays, and working with experienced protection engineers to better understand modern challenges and provide better context for the applications of this research.

Impact:

The two primary research areas of interest for this project were IBR control, and transmission protective relaying. Existing transmission protection functions, such as distance & directional, that rely on negative sequence quantities for proper operation are vulnerable to the inconsistent & somewhat unknown fault response of commercially available grid following inverters. This concern in part led to the development of IEEE standard 2800. This research shows that by implementing the proposed IBR control strategy, the existing protection infrastructure will continue to operate properly as renewable penetration increases, without the need for equipment upgrades or operational downtime. This is a substantial cost savings for electric utilities.  If IBR manufacturers were to implement this strategy, it would meet the requirements of IEEE2800, and ensure that existing transmission protection devices will operate as expected. This proposed control strategy only impacts the fault response of the inverters, and able to be implemented regardless of specific proprietary control logic during normal operating conditions. It does not require any additional hardware and should be feasible to implement for existing IBR systems.

This research is transformative in the control and design of inverters for the inverter-based resources (IBRs) so that the existing relaying infrastructure doesn’t need to be replaced. This, in turn, will lower the cost of IBR interconnection, by avoiding the cost of system-wide protection upgrade, leading to greater penetration of renewables with the goal toward their hundred-percent penetration. The control scheme is based on emulating the time-tested behavior of conventional generators during faults such that all existing relays operate as expected. The proposed scheme requires no modifications in the existing protection infrastructure, i.e., the inverters operate based on local measurements only and thereby keeping costs low and minimizing deployment effort. An important goal of this research is technology transfer based on the real and immediate need of the industry. Although focused on utility-scale use of renewable energy sources, it can also be applied to utility-scale battery storage systems, and large DC microgrids connected to the transmission and sub-transmission voltage levels. As an outcome of this project, transmission owners can require renewable power producers to have appropriate control in their inverters that they acquired from inverter vendors.

Synergistic to this research, through an ONR grant, a sustainability-focused curriculum of graduate-level courses in power systems, power electronics, and electric machines/drives is being promoted. This research is at the intersection of power electronics, power systems, and controls, and will be very educational for the next generation of power engineers.
